quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Normally I spend a lot of time researching how the best companies and the best product leaders operate, but you can learn a lot and often a lot more from failure.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A contrarian learning model: prioritize studying failures because they can be more instructive than success cases.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: And so what we've done with this episode is we've looked at all of the past episodes we've done and pulled out all the most interesting and insightful stories of failure and turned it into this very focused episode on failure.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A practical methodology: systematically mine past work for failure stories and curate them into a focused learning artifact.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Let us know what you think in the comments on YouTube or on lennysnewsletter.com, or just let me know on Twitter. If you like this, we'll keep doing this. If not, we'll, probably not.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: An execution pattern: solicit feedback across channels and use it to decide whether to continue investing in an initiative.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: In-app communication has the highest conversion, highest engagement, and highest satisfaction of any communication channel.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A clear performance claim that can influence channel strategy decisions for product and growth teams.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: In-app communication has the highest conversion, highest engagement, and highest satisfaction of any communication channel.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Sendbird)
quotes.context: A clear prioritization data point suggesting in-app messaging can outperform email/SMS/push for key business outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Experimentation is increasingly essential for driving growth and for understanding the performance of new features.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Eppo)
quotes.context: Reinforces experimentation as a core operating methodology for product teams, not a nice-to-have.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: When I was at Airbnb, one of the things that I loved most was our experimentation platform where I could set up experiments, easily, troubleshoot issues, and analyze performance all on my own.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Eppo)
quotes.context: Highlights the practitioner advantage of self-serve experimentation tooling that reduces dependency on specialized analysts/engineers.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Eppo does all that and more with advanced statistical methods that can help you shave weeks off experiment time, an accessible UI for diving deeper into performance, and out-of-the-box reporting that helps you avoid annoying prolonged analytic cycles.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Eppo)
quotes.context: Actionable criteria for evaluating experimentation platforms: faster time-to-results, deeper analysis, and reduced reporting overhead.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Eppo also makes it easy for you to share experiment insights with your team, sparking new ideas for the A/B testing flywheel.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Eppo)
quotes.context: Introduces a repeatable growth loop mental model where sharing learnings increases the rate and quality of future experiments.

quotes.topic_title: Airbnb design team rebellion and trust
quotes.text: And regardless of each individual thing, what was very clear was that the missing piece, the theme that was across all of that is that I hadn't earned their trust.
quotes.speaker: Katie Dill
quotes.context: Distills the root-cause diagnosis into a single leadership variable—earned trust—rather than debating individual feedback points.

quotes.topic_title: Airbnb design team rebellion and trust
quotes.text: So whether how right or how wrong what I was doing was is the key piece is that I wasn't bringing the team along with me.
quotes.speaker: Katie Dill
quotes.context: Highlights that correctness isn’t sufficient for change; alignment and inclusion are required to make progress stick.

quotes.topic_title: Airbnb design team rebellion and trust
quotes.text: And really a key part in building trust was to listen, to hear out what the individuals on the team were setting out to do, what they cared about, what motivated them.
quotes.speaker: Katie Dill
quotes.context: Gives a concrete, repeatable method for rebuilding trust: structured listening focused on goals, values, and motivations.

quotes.topic_title: Airbnb design team rebellion and trust
quotes.text: You can inflict change on people, but if you want to do it with them, really trust is the key element there.
quotes.speaker: Katie Dill
quotes.context: Offers a memorable mental model contrasting imposed change vs. co-created change, with trust as the enabling mechanism.

quotes.topic_title: Airbnb design team rebellion and trust
quotes.text: And then a couple of months later, we had the best engagement scores in the company.
quotes.speaker: Katie Dill
quotes.context: Provides an outcome metric showing that the trust-and-listen shift produced measurable organizational improvement.

quotes.topic_title: Freezing on stage and recovering
quotes.text: Some things have happened in work, are very memorable at the time and they don't really scar you.
quotes.speaker: Paul Adams
quotes.context: A useful perspective shift: many intense work moments feel huge but don’t leave lasting damage, which can reduce fear and overreaction.

quotes.topic_title: Freezing on stage and recovering
quotes.text: It was the first ever time in my life I'd rehearsed a talk word for word. Usually, I have talking points and I'd ad lib and things get mixed around and it's kind of informal.
quotes.speaker: Paul Adams
quotes.context: A concrete, practitioner-relevant contrast between rigid scripting vs. flexible talking points that can inform how people prepare for high-stakes talks.

quotes.topic_title: Freezing on stage and recovering
quotes.text: But I can manage to turn it around, I walked back out, I'd kind of been disarmed internally in my head, and the rest of it went well.
quotes.speaker: Paul Adams
quotes.context: A vivid recovery playbook in one line: reset internally, re-enter, and continue—showing failure doesn’t have to end the performance.

quotes.topic_title: Freezing on stage and recovering
quotes.text: When life kind of throws you these whatever curve balls you have got to kind of adapt, and it's not that big a deal. None of these things are that big a deal. At the end of the day you kind of move on, live and learn.
quotes.speaker: Paul Adams
quotes.context: A resilience mental model: adapt in the moment, downshift the perceived stakes, and treat the event as learning rather than identity-defining.

quotes.topic_title: Freezing on stage and recovering
quotes.text: You can turn it around. Yeah.
quotes.speaker: Paul Adams
quotes.context: A simple, memorable reminder that even worst-case public failures can be recoverable in real time.

quotes.topic_title: Google social product failures and fear-driven strategy
quotes.text: I think a lot of the motivation for those projects came from a place of fear. It didn't come from a place of let's make a great product for people,.let's really understand the things people struggle with when communicating with family and friends. That's really, really try and create something wonderful. It came from a place of fear.
quotes.speaker: Paul Adams
quotes.context: A clear mental model contrasting fear-driven competitive strategy vs. user-need-driven product building.

quotes.topic_title: Google social product failures and fear-driven strategy
quotes.text: Google Buzz was kind of a privacy disaster, and Google+ similar.
quotes.speaker: Paul Adams
quotes.context: A concrete example that highlights how misaligned strategy and execution can manifest as major privacy failures.

quotes.topic_title: Google social product failures and fear-driven strategy
quotes.text: And the same pattern emerged every single time, which was people need way better ways to communicate with small groups of family and friends.
quotes.speaker: Paul Adams
quotes.context: A repeatable research finding practitioners can use to prioritize small-group communication use cases over broad social broadcasting.

quotes.topic_title: Google social product failures and fear-driven strategy
quotes.text: I kind of look back now and go like WhatsApp, or it maybe iMessage if everyone's on Apple, but really obvious in hindsight, but at the time, not obvious.
quotes.speaker: Paul Adams
quotes.context: A counterintuitive reminder that “obvious” product directions often only become clear after the market validates them.

quotes.topic_title: Google social product failures and fear-driven strategy
quotes.text: but the root cause for me is that the project has been run from a place of fear, competitive fear, which I don't think leads to good things.
quotes.speaker: Paul Adams
quotes.context: A memorable warning that competitive fear can distort culture and decision-making, producing bad outcomes even before launch.

quotes.topic_title: Embracing failure through shipping and learning
quotes.text: He said, "At Facebook you can design the product, but at Intercom you can design the company."
quotes.speaker: Paul Adams
quotes.context: A memorable reframing of product leadership as company design, not just product design.

quotes.topic_title: Embracing failure through shipping and learning
quotes.text: I'm a big believer in big bets, higher risk, higher reward.
quotes.speaker: Paul Adams
quotes.context: A clear strategic stance that encourages practitioners to pursue outsized outcomes by accepting higher failure rates.

quotes.topic_title: Embracing failure through shipping and learning
quotes.text: But I get excited about big bets and if you make big bets, you're going to get a lot of it wrong.
quotes.speaker: Paul Adams
quotes.context: A counterintuitive reminder that frequent failure is an expected cost of ambitious bets, not a signal to stop.

quotes.topic_title: Embracing failure through shipping and learning
quotes.text: Ship fast, ship early, ship often is what it says now.
quotes.speaker: Paul Adams
quotes.context: A practical operating principle teams can adopt to accelerate learning cycles through frequent shipping.

quotes.topic_title: Embracing failure through shipping and learning
quotes.text: So there's a real tension there, a real trade-off where people have these high standards, which we encourage and we encourage them to ship fast and learn and make mistakes. It's a constant kind of tension that we're navigating.
quotes.speaker: Paul Adams
quotes.context: Highlights the enduring leadership challenge of balancing craft/quality with speed and learning.

quotes.topic_title: Pets.com: overfunding, arms races, and timing
quotes.text: So there is, I think a fundamental lesson about having an excess of investment can be its own albatross or lead you to make decisions that maybe would be unwise.
quotes.speaker: Tom Conrad
quotes.context: A counterintuitive funding lesson: too much capital can distort decision-making and push teams into irrational competition.

quotes.topic_title: Pets.com: overfunding, arms races, and timing
quotes.text: we all thought it was a zero-sum game and that we as one player started to spend on promotion or to spend irrationally on national broadcast television advertising. We all did, and it became this kind of unwinnable arms race.
quotes.speaker: Tom Conrad
quotes.context: Describes the “arms race” dynamic that can emerge in overfunded markets and how it drives wasteful spend.

quotes.topic_title: Pets.com: overfunding, arms races, and timing
quotes.text: Probably can't make it work when 80% of the country on the internet is still on dial up. It's really, really early.
quotes.speaker: Tom Conrad
quotes.context: A timing/market-readiness heuristic: even viable business models fail when infrastructure and user behavior aren’t ready.

quotes.topic_title: Pets.com: overfunding, arms races, and timing
quotes.text: we actually didn't go bankrupt. We shut the company down and returned the remaining balance to the investors, which no public company had ever done before.
quotes.speaker: Tom Conrad
quotes.context: A notable shutdown strategy example that prioritizes capital stewardship over “fighting to the last dollar.”

quotes.topic_title: Pets.com: overfunding, arms races, and timing
quotes.text: And so it was better to wind down early, take the money that we had in the bank and get it back to investors than to just spend every last penny on what was sort of a fruitless attempt to salvage it.
quotes.speaker: Tom Conrad
quotes.context: Actionable decision principle: when the path to more capital/profitability is gone, an early wind-down can be the most responsible move.

quotes.topic_title: Quibi: rekindled passion and broken business math
quotes.text: But I think the thing I've come to better appreciate is that companies are also, they're kind of a math problem that describes how you take investment and pour them into the equation, and out the other side comes returns on some time horizon.
quotes.speaker: Tom Conrad
quotes.context: A useful mental model: evaluate startups not just on product quality, but on whether the investment-to-returns equation can work.

quotes.topic_title: Quibi: rekindled passion and broken business math
quotes.text: But if the equation is fundamentally broken or a big swing in and of itself, no amount of iteration and execution can get you out of the failed outputs of the broken equation.
quotes.speaker: Tom Conrad
quotes.context: Contrarian reminder that great execution can’t rescue a business with broken unit economics or an unrealistic bet.

quotes.topic_title: Quibi: rekindled passion and broken business math
quotes.text: And I think Quibi made a bet that you could build an entirely bespoke content library that was sufficiently scaled to get people to subscribe and retain for a couple billion dollars.
quotes.speaker: Tom Conrad
quotes.context: A concrete example of a high-stakes assumption practitioners can pressure-test early: content spend required to drive subscription + retention.

quotes.topic_title: Quibi: rekindled passion and broken business math
quotes.text: we made 70 shows in 18 months, which is more content than all of the major broadcast networks combined made in a single year.
quotes.speaker: Tom Conrad
quotes.context: Specific scale benchmark illustrating how massive execution can still be insufficient if the underlying business math doesn’t work.

quotes.topic_title: Quibi: rekindled passion and broken business math
quotes.text: And we launched two weeks into Covid, and we couldn't make any of that content except literally in the garages of the host's homes.
quotes.speaker: Tom Conrad
quotes.context: Operational lesson: external shocks can invalidate key production assumptions, so resilience/contingency planning matters.

quotes.topic_title: Fail conclusively: designing experiments to learn
quotes.text: Growth experiments in my history are typically like 30%-ish success rate. So the vast majority of things that you try don't work.
quotes.speaker: Sri Batchu
quotes.context: A concrete benchmark that normalizes failure rates in growth work and sets expectations for experimentation culture.

quotes.topic_title: Fail conclusively: designing experiments to learn
quotes.text: And for me, failure is not that you didn't drive revenue, failure is not learning.
quotes.speaker: Sri Batchu
quotes.context: A memorable redefinition of failure that shifts teams from outcome-fixation to learning-focused experimentation.

quotes.topic_title: Fail conclusively: designing experiments to learn
quotes.text: But at the end of the day, there's only two ways to make an experiment successful. Either you have a very large M or you have a very significant treatment, which is what you're doing in the experiment itself.
quotes.speaker: Sri Batchu
quotes.context: A simple experiment-design mental model: compensate for small samples by increasing treatment effect size.

quotes.topic_title: Fail conclusively: designing experiments to learn
quotes.text: And so to counteract that, I recommend people just trying to maximize the treatment effect, which is like if you have a hypothesis that you're testing, just throw all of the possible tactics and resources that you think would move that needle because you can always cost rationalize later if it works.
quotes.speaker: Sri Batchu
quotes.context: Counterintuitive advice for B2B testing: go “all in” on the first test to get a conclusive learning signal, then optimize cost later.

quotes.topic_title: Fail conclusively: designing experiments to learn
quotes.text: And if with all of that it didn't work, then you can say, "Hey, we're not going to try this again because we literally did try everything that we could to test this hypothesis. And if it doesn't work in the best version, and it's expensive as it is, this is not worth spending more time on."
quotes.speaker: Sri Batchu
quotes.context: A practical decision rule for preventing repeated inconclusive experiments and stopping ideas from resurfacing endlessly.

quotes.topic_title: Airbnb Plus: solution-first thinking and unit economics
quotes.text: I think something that is really hard to untrain, but I think every human does it, is you jump to solutions.
quotes.speaker: Jiaona Zhang (JZ)
quotes.context: A core PM mental model: recognize and actively unlearn solution-first instincts before doing problem discovery.

quotes.topic_title: Airbnb Plus: solution-first thinking and unit economics
quotes.text: We essentially were like, "Let's go inspect our inventory. Let's actually try to manage our inventory more." And really what we should have done is taken a step back and be like, "What's the real problem?" The real problem is people want to know what they're getting themselves into. We need to represent the homes a lot better.
quotes.speaker: Jiaona Zhang (JZ)
quotes.context: A concrete example of misdiagnosing the problem (trust/representation) and over-investing in an operational solution (inspections).

quotes.topic_title: Airbnb Plus: solution-first thinking and unit economics
quotes.text: Not to mention the unit economics. Are the unit economics actually going to work, even as you scale?
quotes.speaker: Jiaona Zhang (JZ)
quotes.context: A reminder to pressure-test unit economics early, especially when adding operational complexity to a marketplace model.

quotes.topic_title: Airbnb Plus: solution-first thinking and unit economics
quotes.text: You're like, "Well, when we get to the scale of X, it's all going to work out. We can make these things happen." I think you actually need to really make sure the unit economics work right at the beginning.
quotes.speaker: Jiaona Zhang (JZ)
quotes.context: A contrarian warning against “it’ll work at scale” thinking—validate economics upfront rather than hoping scale fixes them.

quotes.topic_title: Airbnb Plus: solution-first thinking and unit economics
quotes.text: So for example, it is actually cheaper to go send everyone a lockbox than to deploy an inspector and go look at your property, right?
quotes.speaker: Jiaona Zhang (JZ)
quotes.context: A specific tactic illustrating targeted, lower-cost interventions that address quality issues without heavy operations.

quotes.topic_title: Career A-side vs B-side and hidden setbacks
quotes.text: We are very encouraged in our lives, especially professionally, to talk about our A side all the time because that's what impresses people.
quotes.speaker: Gina Gotthilf
quotes.context: Introduces the A-side/B-side career framework and why public narratives skew toward highlights.

quotes.topic_title: Career A-side vs B-side and hidden setbacks
quotes.text: So it means that a lot of what you hear in podcasts and on stage ends up being the Instagramable version of someone or a company or a country's trajectory. It's just the highlights.
quotes.speaker: Gina Gotthilf
quotes.context: A counterintuitive reminder to discount “highlight reel” stories when benchmarking your own progress.

quotes.topic_title: Career A-side vs B-side and hidden setbacks
quotes.text: But I really like to highlight those because I think that most of us have a lot of B moments every day, every week, every month, and every period of our lives.
quotes.speaker: Gina Gotthilf
quotes.context: Normalizes frequent setbacks as a recurring pattern rather than a personal anomaly.

quotes.topic_title: Career A-side vs B-side and hidden setbacks
quotes.text: And so that for me, I think my one learning there that has stuck with me, and I think it can work for other people too, is that it's not just about doing things that actually matter and learning. It's about being able to tell the story, and it's about understanding what other people perceive as valuable.
quotes.speaker: Gina Gotthilf
quotes.context: Actionable career advice: outcomes aren’t enough—packaging and perceived value shape opportunities.

quotes.topic_title: Career A-side vs B-side and hidden setbacks
quotes.text: So for example, they couldn't figure out how to wire money to Brazil. So I was not paid for six months.
quotes.speaker: Gina Gotthilf
quotes.context: A concrete example of hidden operational setbacks that can exist even inside “made it” moments.
